channel.title: CNET News.com
channel.description: Tech news and business reports by CNET News.com. Focused on information technology, core topics include computers, hardware, software, networking, and Internet media.

item.title: Don't count out Juniper -- yet.
item.description: Blog: It's not a fun time at Juniper Networks. The company is suffering through a perfect storm of an aging product line, SEC investigations,...

item.title: Mobile-TV vendors politely jockey for position
item.description: TV on mobile phones is still new enough to support many approaches, as carriers push to get short videos onto phones.

item.title: Windows in view
item.description: special coverage With the launch of Vista fast approaching, it's crunch time for Microsoft at WinHEC.

item.title: Microsoft primes PC buyers for Premium Vista
item.description: Forget Vista Basic. Microsoft's marketing campaign will pitch hard for people to choose the higher-end Windows update.

item.title: Rumor: Apple to sell PowerSchool
item.description: Blog: Mac rumor sites are reporting today that Apple Computer will sell PowerSchool, its Web-based student information system, to Pearson...

item.title: Europe: No patents for software
item.description: Apparent U-turn on the extent to which software can be patented leaves patent opponents scratching their heads.

item.title: AOL eyes broadband and advertising
item.description: Time Warner unit to launch new search function targeting high-speed connections, CEO says.

item.title: $100 laptop gets working prototype
item.description:
Nicholas Negroponte's One Laptop Per Child project shows off a vivid orange PC and trims its software load.
Photos: Laptop model sees orange

item.title: Can we generate power by walking?
item.description: Also on News.com Extra: Leaks feared as sacked MI6 spy launches blog.

item.title: Sensors: Living off scraps of energy
item.description:
In the future, your shoes may be able to charge your camera and RFID chips could tell when you leave the room.
Images: Energy-saving sensors

item.title: Mozilla CEO: Why we're still shunned by corporate IT
item.description: Businesses still stick with proprietary technology, although Mozilla offers customization kit for business customers.

item.title: The ultimate Web 2.0 metaphor: Legos
item.description: Blog: To the casual observer, it might seem odd to find coverage of a Lego-building contest on a technology news site. But the interlocking...

item.title: E-mail a factor in case against former Bush official
item.description: During opening of David Safavian's trial, prosecutors say messages will prove he lied about links to Jack Abramoff.

item.title: Images: Energy-saving sensors
item.description: Scientists are working on sensors designed to harvest their own energy, in some cases converting mechanical into electrical energy.

item.title: Microsoft lays plans for 'Vistagami' tablets
item.description: Successor to Origami will look like the Windows XP-based tablet PC, but run the Vista update and hopefully cost less.

item.title: Allchin: Still worried about Vista
item.description: Man behind development of newest Windows says there's still plenty of work to do before shipment.

item.title: Video: Broader test versions of the software now ready
item.description: Video: Broader test versions of the software now ready. Mika Krammer, Microsoft Windows marketing director, demonstrates features in Vista and Office 2007 during Chairman Bill Gates' keynote at the WinHEC 2006 conference. The demonstration included a picture frame with SideShow features and touch-screen displays.

item.title: Microsoft improves online maps
item.description: Blog: Last night we got a demo of the new version of Windows Live Local, Microsoft's online mapping system [See News.com story]. It...

item.title: Sales of LCD TVs going like crazy
item.description: Shipments of liquid crystal display televisions jump in the first quarter, along with revenue.

item.title: Deal of the day: Sony Vaio for $900

item.description: Blog: Among the more than 3,500 attendees at Microsoft's annual event for hardware experts are some perhaps unexpected visitors: Apple...
